review_title: Recommended for audiophiles who love bass
review_text: I started out with the new Sony WF1000-XM3 earbuds. They got great reviews and I always try to buy the best - price is secondary to sound, for me. After using them for a day or two, I found myself very disappointed in the sound so I went back to the store to see if there was something better. These new Jabras caught my eye, with their small size. I read the specs and was impressed with the battery life. I knew the 65t was good, so I figured this would be 10 better. I exchanged the Sonys and brought the Jabras home. I have to say, I am very impressed with the sound these little guys put out. The bass is OUTSTANDING, to the point where I have considered EQing it down (and I love bass). What's really great though, is that the rest of the frequencies are well represented, even in the face of all that low-end. It's like a car system with really good mids and highs, but then a sub in the back. (Obviously not as good as a real sub, but you get the idea.) The size and fit are great too, a really impressive bit of engineering. I haven't tested max battery life, because they're always in the charging case when not in my ears and I don't listen for *that* long. Speaking of charging case, I really like how small it is - much smaller than the Sony case. I can fit it in my front jeans pocket along with my Note 9! The app is useful and appealing to the eye. It has a 5-band EQ that you can save your own presets into. I bumped the top end a tiny bit but otherwise the sound is on point right out of the box. If you are an audiophile who loves bass, and you want the best on the market, I recommend these Jabra 75t earbuds without reservation. (These should have a 5-star average, but some people don't get how product reviews work.)

I have several of the 65t version. They fit my ear perfectly! With the 75t I can’t get a solid fit which means I can’t get a solid sound unfortunately. I really wanted to like the new design and was a different about upgrading. Probably won’t be using these.

So what are you looking for in an earbud? If it is a pair that is wireless, small and comfy, look great, and have great sound and battery life, these could be in your future. The first thing you want to do is download the app and update the firmware. That will take about 15 minutes, but you will be up and running afterwards. My favorite feature is the ability to tweak the EQ to taste. This alone will make it easy to get great sound no matter what you favor. Once you get the sound to your taste, you will notice clear separation of instruments and very good out of the head type of sound. Some people refer to this as "head stage". In my experience, these rival some open backed headphones for the out of the head sound quality. Next, the battery life is very good on these earbuds. You get around 7.5 hours on a charge and you can charge them in their portable case which will get you up to 28 hours of battery without needing to plug them in. The main shortfall here is that you can't listen to one while the other charges. Well, you can charge the left bud and listen to the right one, but you can't listen while charging the right bud. That being said, you can get an extra hour of play with a 15 minute charge. The controls on these buds is second to none. You can even control volume without evoking Siri. They also have the ability to connect to 8 different devices and 2 can be connected simultaneously. I tested this with a Mac and an iPhone. You can be listening on the Mac, pause music and start playing on the iPhone and it will simply switch right over. That is cool! It works the other way around, as well. These don't offer active noise cancelling. However, the bud fits in the ear canal deep enough that it blocks out most sound. They include a tech call "hear through" that uses the mics to make it easy to hear what is going on around you, though. There is a slight hum when you have this feature turned up all the way, but you can put it half way up and still be able to hear around you without the hum. For best sound quality, I would recommend turning this feature off. All in all, I am very happy with these buds. I really like the looks and sound quality of them. My only gripe is the inability to charge the right bud while listening to the left bud. This would be great for charging while listening to a podcast. However, everything else hits the mark.

review_title: Unfinished product with lots of bugs and issues.
review_text: I would like to start off saying that I have tried multiple earbuds and I was really looking forward for an airpod pro alternative that wouldn’t break my bank as much . If I were to rank or refer someone to buy the best overall sound earbud , I would recommend them the Bose Soundsport , followed by the Powerbeats pro and then perphaps the 75t. Ear fatigue on these earbuds is eminent . I wore them a for a little over an hour and my ear canal was already hurting . I have also noticed the 75t only works with the right earbud as the master and the left earbud as the slave. The Powerbeats pro can work independently. I haven’t tried the call quality on the 75t but it is because of all the flaws it has , have forced me to put them down and continue using my older earbuds. I just wished they would have done a better job with the sound quality. Maybe a firmware update will fix this issue but for the time being , I wouldn’t recommend them . I would rather tell people to buy the 65t active that is going refurbished for less than $80 or to get themselves a refurbished powerbeats pro which offers a well balance sound , a comfortable experience , long battery life and great connection with your ios device.

review_title: These are great earbuds that could have been the total package, but miss the mark for me.
review_text:
For TLDR readers here are some quick scores out of the box

CAN'T LISTEN TO THE LEFT EARBUD WITHOUT THE RIGHT. Detailed review
I got these at the spur of the moment the other day while at best buy, I had heard Jabras had a really good sound quality and figured at the very least I will have a good set of back up buds if my Galaxybuds are out of juice or I forget them somewhere. After a very long update, I got right in to listening to music and was instantly impressed with how full the sound was, I compared these to my Samsung Galaxy buds and these made them sound flat by comparison, but noticed pretty quickly that they kind of hurt my ears. don't get me wrong, the shape is great and can be worn for hours with no issues, but the ear tips that come with them have a blunt tip to them leaving an almost squarish tip that really bothered my ear especially when removing them. I switched the tips with some with a more rounded tip and they are so much more comfortable, I cant hardly feel them in my ear at all. The App is great for these earbuds and the EQ setting makes a would of difference in the sound quality, unlike some cheaper earbuds. I would like it if there was a way to share EQ profiles like with the Jay Birds that my brother has, I'm not the best in the world at turning an EQ so it would be nice to see how others have theirs set. The audio passthrough is a nice feature and works just as well as the Samsung galaxy does, but with 1 big difference, you can use the passthrough with just 1 earbud in which is a nice touch. If you are afraid of losing an earbud these are perfect for you. These hare a GPS feature that shows the last location that they were connected, but they also have a find by sound mode that will save so much time if you lose them outside like brother and his jaybirds, that was a nightmare. My one real complaint is that if you want to listen to 1 earbud it has to the right earbud, its this reason these will not be my main set of earbuds. It is so annoying laying in bed with my girlfriend to my right and not be able to hear her if I'm listening to something when I wanted to be considerate and not make her listen to my video or music, but because of that I get chewed out for not listening to her just because my earbuds don't have what should be a basic feature, so I will be sticking with my Galaxy buds even though they don't sound as good. I really wanted to give these 3 stars just for this, but that would not be fair to how well these perform. Honestly Jabra, how can you not listen to the left earbud without the right this late in the game? My girlfriend has a 15 dollar air pod knock offs that can do it, and here I am with earbuds that run close to $200 feeling like a joke.

review_title: The Pros, Cons and Oks for Jabra Elite 75t Earbuds (HR).
review_text:
Pros:__________
• Very small, compact, and a sleek design compare too many out there. Wearing these Jabra provides a minimalistic look that doesn’t draw any attention. This is something that Apple will never get back. • They have a secure tight fit. From my experience, there is no way that these earbuds will leave your ear unless you use your hands. I ran, went on a trampoline, and bobbled my head up and down when listening to Jimi Hendrix. Very sturdy, no wobble whatsoever. • They are comfortable to wear. The 75t rest on your ears, rather than relying on all the stability near the speaker end. Secure and comfort. • Excellent connection. No hiccups using them as a phone or just for music. Bluetooth 5.0, the 75t allows you to connect to your phone and another device if you want. • The case can go up to 28 hours. I didn’t test to see if this number is correct, but I did need to charge it after a week of use. • The case itself is super small and can be stood upright. Think Apple’s noise-canceling Airpods charging case, but a little smaller. My wallet and keys both can be fit in one pants pocket with this. • Magnetic seal on the case makes it to opens easily, and stays shut when you want it. The strength of the magnet can hold the earbuds upside down with them falling off. • The case has USB-C fast charging. A 10-minute charge gave the case 40 minutes more battery life. • You can check the battery levels for the case and the earbuds with the app (more details about the app later on). • The microphone layout is excellent. The 75t has a 4 microphone setup, making a conversation very clear on their end. I walked through the wind and there was little to none wind distortion on the other end. These microphones help isolate the outside noises so your voice is the only one that is focused. They work and they work well. • They put in a built-in mute button on the earbuds. Small perks go a long way Jabra, thanks. • One-touch on the earbuds and you got Alexa, Google, or Siri on your end, if you’re connected to your phone. • Sweat and dust resistant. Sweat all you like, these buds will keep going. • One of the best features is the app for these. With the 75t’s app, you can personalize your sound take that fits your comfort. The layout is very user-friendly as you are given a visual graphic display of how much you want to the sound quality to either your right, left or both earbuds. I’m a firm believer in enabling the use of custom sound profiles because only you know what’s best for your hearing. With a lot of customization with this, I’m very happy. • Another cool feature of the app is if you apply your personal sound settings, the earbuds will automatically adapt to what you’re changing in the app. No delay or restarting them. • Sound-wise: One of the best bass levels on the market. If you’re a bass person, you’ll love this in every way. If you’re not then you can just go in the app and reduce it. • The mids and highs are crisp, while the Passive Noise reduction does a respectable job blocking out those outside noises. • Pulling out my earbuds, they automatically stop whatever music I was playing. Quick sensors. • The tap controls are very simple and accurate. The best part for me with this is that you have the option to control the volume controls on the earbuds themselves. No need to go on the phone. Cons and Oks:__________
• The bass. It’s really good but too good. It overpowers the highs and lows of the music to a point it’s always boom, boom, boom. I immediately went to the app and cut down the bass. Sadly the bass power is still there, but defiantly not that significant. For bass needed songs, this an upside, but I’m not a bass person myself. • No built-in noise-canceling software. The Passive Noise reduction works well when the wind is blowing in your face. It does reduce a significant amount of wind resistance but other than that a loud environment will still be a loud environment in the earbuds. • Low water rating. Only sweat resistance so you have to be extra careful when the rain or snow comes into your world. These are great for running, but it’s a turn off knowing that you have to be careful not the get these buds wet. • Bulky in the ear. They are small but I felt these buds look like they’re going to pop out of my ear. Extend the earbuds as Apple did so they can be thin and not look like large jelly beans. • No wireless charging for the case. • You get on average a less full day of battery life. This isn’t the greatest as other reviewers have had worse, so be warned. • There is a tight deal suction with these buds. I have no issue but I know some aren’t a fan of the suction feeling and would like some air coming in. This is especially a must if you’re a runner. • The left earbud can be used independently. The right can but not the left. Jabra states for a software update in 2020, so it’s a wait and sees. • Changing your setting with these buds are not automatic. A couple of times I had to wait for the buds to adapt to the settings I made on the app. This only occurs when they’re significant changes. • I used an iPhone and you can’t call up Siri with these. You have to go to the phone. • Those with large hands may have difficulty using these, because of the size. • I tried connecting my computer and phone at the same time and the buds got a glitch. It’s trying to find what primary use is, and when your phone goes off when you’re watching a YouTube video, it has a hard time to choose which one to give you. • With a small bulky size, numerous times I accidentally press the wrong buttons on the buds. There is a learning curve on where to press. Bottom Line:__________
For the active lifestyle for working out, these are quite good. I couldn’t get them out of my ears unless I physically took them out. Also, I was most impressed with the customization you can do for sound when using the app. To be able to configure the sound experience that fits your needs is spot on, and is something that every headphone needs to provide. With a small design, and great microphone setup, and an excellent battery case, I felt these are earbuds that I can be taken on the go while not making people staring at me (unlike Apple). But still that bass. It’s really good when the music matches it, but very annoying when there is bass in songs that don’t need it. The app does help, but with the price you’re paying you to expect the default sound to be neutral. Also the pricing is up with the big guys (Apple, Samsung, etc) so I expected to get some form of noise-canceling software, but sadly no. In the end, there are decent earbuds but with a mediocre battery life, my expectations were higher given the price. Overall: A decent sound with a strong bass but a battery life nothing to brag about. Hope I was a help to you. Love,
Honest Reviewer

review_title: I'd give them 6 stars if I could
review_text:
I have had a bunch of wireless ear buds over the years, almost all on the expensive side of the spectrum ($250+). Bragi, Sennheiser, Bang & Olefsun among a few others. The 75t's put them all to shame in almost every category. They're the best true wireless ear buds I've found and it's not even close. I've only had them for a few days and haven't had to test the battery life just yet, so I won't comment on that. But in every other way these are damn near perfect. Pros:
- First and foremost: INCREDIBLE connectivity. I haven't experienced a single dropout with these yet, either from the device or between left and right. I live and commute in NYC and there are places where other more expensive bluetooth sets were simply unusable because of all the interference. For the most part you would expect a dropout at least every few minutes just walking down the street. None of that with these. I've seen plenty of other sets advertise this kind of connectivity but these are the first that truly deliver on it. - They are the smallest and lightest pair I've ever seen with an incredibly thin profile. They're almost invisible from the front when you have them in. - Even though they're small they have a really great fit. I can't imagine them falling out and yet they're still incredibly comfortable. You notice the first time you take them out that you have to really PULL them which gives you confidence they're not going to fall out on their own. - There's no active noise cancellation, but you don't miss it. The tight fit shuts out noise almost perfectly. And the lack of noise cancelling software running means increased battery life. - Sound quality is exceptional and the app-based EQ is great to fine tune for music or speech. I don't notice any difference in the sound quality between these and pairs that cost twice as much although I suppose some audiophiles might quibble. But if that's your thing you probably aren't using bluetooth headsets. I don't quite understand the other reviews complaining that the bass is overpowering. Even in default mode I think it's great and you can easily bring it down with the EQ.
- Microphone is also as good as I've ever found. On calls people have no idea I'm on bluetooth and the Hearthrough transparency feature is much clearer than similar features I've used in more expensive sets. You can even adjust the level with the app which is handy since you might want more or less transparency say in the office versus on the street. - The controls on the buds are mechanical instead of touch-sensitive like on most more expensive models, and while that does pose something to potentially malfunction down the line, I actually prefer it as the touch sensitive controls on other sets I've had were always very finicky, often making me have to tap them multiple times to get any response which also made multi-tap functions next to impossible. With these you just click and everything works as advertised. - The battery level LED indicators are a great feature to quickly see if you're running low on either the buds or the charger with a quick flip of the lid. - The app is fantastic, showing battery life for the buds and charging case, enabling audio customization, microphone sensitivity, and even a GPS locator (I haven't tested if this will find one of the buds or the case separately but it's still a nice feature in case you ever misplace the set)
Cons:
- Honestly, I can't think of any. If they could develop a more reliable touch-sensitive control and replace the mechanical ones I guess that would be nice, although probably more expensive. Bottom Line:
If you're in the market, these are the buds to buy. They easily surpass $300+ sets across the board. I'll be excited to see how Jarba improves on them even further in future models.

review_title: Don’t believe the naysayers, the Jabra 75t’s are SOLID
review_text: For anyone who’s had a defective pair of these, or if they’ve stopped working after a short period of time, that really stinks. I have to believe that’s unusual. For the rest of us, here’s a review that is balanced and fair. It’s laughable to read some reviews where some people are so utterly disgusted with a product. It’s never, ever that bad. Some people are just mad at life and if the ear pods don’t make you a sandwich, they’re rated as trash. I currently have the AirPods Pro and the Jabra 75t. I’ve recently tried and returned the Power Beats Pro and the Sennheiser Momentum 2’s. By the way, if you make phone calls, avoid the Sennheiser’s. Unbelievable, phenomenally good sound quality, but mostly unusable for calls due to their awkward mic placement. And they’re $320 with tax. Now for the Jabra’s. These fit me far better than any I’ve tried. Tight and they fill your ear, but not uncomfortably so. These create a great seal even without ANC. The AirPods Pro are fantastic, but I happen to have trouble keeping the left one in my ear if I’m at all active, walking or running, regardless of the adjustable earpiece size. That’s a me problem, not Apple’s. The Jabra’s stay in, create a nice seal, require little to no adjusting while active and sound great. Don’t let the naysayers scare you off, these are a solid pick and customizable with the EQ in the app to help zero in on just about any sound preference. For me, fit is critical, a close second is the ability to tweak the sound, then call quality and finally, compatibility with connecting with my iPhone and ease of use. The Jabra’s have plenty of bass, maybe a bit too much for some out of the box, but a small tweak of the EQ should fix it. The low, mid and high ranges aren’t Sennheiser quality, not should they be at $179. Music is crisp, rich and deep. From 80’s metal to Maroon 5, to jazz, I ran through my library and was very impressed and pleased with what I heard. Call quality. Not quite as sharp and clear as the AirPods Pro, but awfully close. The AirPods may slightly edge out Jabra in overall comfort and I’d say there’s definitely a bit more of a “feel like I have cotton stuffed in my ears” with the Jabra’s due to the tighter seal and design. The case size is perfect, couldn’t be better, compact and right on the money. Battery life, so far is great. I’d recommend you give these a shot. If you’re like me and struggle with the AirPods Pro staying in your ears, these won’t disappoint.

review_title: Overall good earbuds but a little expensive.

I get a little worried running in them but they've never fallen out. That was my biggest fear getting expensive earbuds. But I often wear them for hours at a time with no issue. They do have Android Assistant integration but I haven't really figured out how to utilize that too much. I do miss my Google wired earbuds with the assistant button built in. But I can't really fault these for not being as seamless as a Google product. I do have a few issues. Primarily call volume can be a little low. I'm not really sure why this is the case, but I have noticed that sometimes I switch to my handset because I just can't hear the person on the line too well. I know there's a ton of variables at play here, but I've never had this problem with wired earbuds or the handset. I wish I could overboost the call volume somehow. And my BIGGEST complaint is that often the earbud just does not charge in the case. I have had problems where I have the charging case plugged in, and put my earbuds in overnight, and in the morning they're not charged. I've put the earbud in, seen the red light blink indicating it's charging, and STILL have it not charge. So that gets really annoying. Overall these are really nice and I use them daily. But I'm just glad I didn't spend the money on them.

review_title: Great sound quality, fit, and ease-of-use features. AMAZING battery life!
review_text:
* TLDR *
Sleek looking pair of buds with nice compact charging case. App downloaded, immediately paired the buds, ran updates, and they are great! I had to swap out the gels for a different size, but three sizes were included. Sound quality is fantastic, great range, battery life is unmatched from every other wireless bud I've owned. The feature set is more significant than anything I've had, not sure if they are common in their price range. The app is intuitive and has anything you'd need, and the in-app quick start guide was a quick 2 minute read, and enough to get a handle on which bud did what and how within a couple of minutes. After using these, I would have EASILY paid $300 for them. Would I have been prepared to do that before using them? Probably not. * Long-winded *
Coming from wireless buds that were in the sub $50 range, I feel like I'm seeing fire for the first time. Outside of the incredible sound quality and range on these things, little convenience tweaks that will make ease of use so simple. If I pull a bud out of an ear, it pauses playback. Or I can press a button and hear what's around me and not the phone audio. Phone App: configuration profiles to quickly adjust bulk settings on the fly with one tap. They are also in the persistent tray notification on downslide (Android 10). You can tell they really put work into the app to make it easy to use for people of all technical levels. I have a few nit-picky things and quick settings that may annoy me over time, but nothing worth noting (except at the end) - I'm sure this is the case with everyone and every app, because, humans. It does have a lot of quick options that reduce taps and repetitive actions, love that. Some sort of battery or usage metrics would be fun to see if only to see/send telemetry on battery usage. Sound quality: phenomenal, about on par with my over-ear $100-200 gaming headsets. Blown away that they were able to pack this amount of punch and battery life into such a small and comfortable in-ear. Noise cancellation: amazing (post gel switch)! I can't hear myself typing this review on a loud keyboard. Range: these have been great so far! I had my phone charging in my office and went down the hall into another room I bounce between at work, and not one bit of drop out, latency, or quality distortion. The same distance for an EarForce 450 would cause dropouts or complete loss if the door in that room were closed, or another person with a wireless headset was in there. Battery Life: A++! The test: 60 min album (Illenium: Ascend), within 1 meter during 95% of playback, EQ at bass boost, volume at 90% (occasionally 100%), HearThrough disabled. Self-reported remaining battery 60 minutes of playback: 100%. THAT IS BONKERS!! Maybe it drops in increments of 10% or something, but a solid hour of basically max playback and not a flinch. Based on my experience, it will last a lot longer than the quoted 7.5 hours on a full charge. With the nature of batteries, this will obvi change over time. ++ UPDATE: after 90 minutes of Ascend album looping, I'm at 95% (so it appears 5% increments). During the last 30 minutes, I had HearThrough on. I assume that uses more battery to turn the mics hot. Fit: as mentioned, had to swap gel, no biggie. I haven't gone running with them yet, but walking around and up and down the stairs, etc. - they are solid in-ear and super snug. Wearing for two hours now, no discomfort. Assistant: I haven't had much of a chance to use the assistant tie in, in the real world, but the selection of phone vs. Alexa was easy and upfront. Based on having conversations with people, with earbuds in, and using HearThrough only for that -- I'm sure the assistant will have no problem hearing commands. Saying "Hey Google" was an immediate wake response, didn't have a problem with wake or with command. Double-press right bud worked great, immediately playback resume. Assistance volume was very low, but I'm sure that's an on-phone setting in the Android mixer. Love the idea of HearThrough. Some of my gaming headsets and helps big time with communicating and not having to remove the device, it'll be especially helpful on public transit on new routes or delays on things. Constructive feedback: I was trying to pause music and turn on HearThrough at the same time. Pressing the button on both buds at the same time, it shuts them both off immediately. An option in the app to pause music if HearThrough is activated via bud (instead of mute, or maybe a choice between the two) would be excellent! Ideally, I'd like to with one button push: pause music and allow HearThrough. When disabled again, auto-start playback. I'll be sure to update this review in a month if anything changes.

review_title: More Battery Life And Bass With No Tradeoffs
review_text: Technical Note: The 75t uses BLE as well as the Bluetooth standard for connection, you want to use BLE as this extends the battery life with the only tradeoff being distance from the transmission device has to be shorter. In some phones, you have to pair twice to ensure you get the BLE connection as well as the standard. I own the old 65t, and I consider that pair to be fantastic. However, being offered these, I was surprised to notice how little has changed in the physical design. The fit is the same, the profile is a bit smaller, but this is not notably different. The software interface remains the same solid UI without much problems. All of the difference is within. As opposed to the 65t, the 75t gets at least 3 more hours of battery life (I was averaging 7 hours under real continuous playing conditions), a better bass profile which does mean that you need to rethink your equalization, and the charging to fast use gives you more time for less charging. These fit better than the Jaybird Vistas as Jabra decided to keep doing everything right that they had been doing. The Jaybird and Jabra brands run neck-to-neck in the competition for the best pair of general consumer earbuds, but right now, Jabra's offering is the best fitting brand with improvements to performance that buying these should be a no-brainer if you are in the market for them. I think the only difference that gives Jaybird's an advantage is that the Jaybird's tend to have better water protection than the Jabra's, but this Jabra 75t is all around an excellent choice.

I don't write many reviews unless I feel something really deserves it, so here we go! First off I moved from the Jabra Active 65t's and most of the issues/gripes I had with the 65t's look to be resolved with the 75t's. I'll cover the gripes/improvements, then some pros and cons. Gripe Number 1: The charging case
The charging case on the 65t's was this weird type of case where you had to squeeze the side or the center to open them, not a pain, just different. The 75t's have that fixed, it's an easy open magnetic case, love the fact it's magnetic and a strong one at that. Gripe Number 2: Earbuds in the case
The 65t's just kind of sat in the case, there was no positive engagement and you had to rely on a light to tell you if they were connected, sometimes if I was in a hurry and I didn't confirm the buds were properly inserted they wouldn't charge, same goes if I needed to open them in a hurry the buds would sometimes pop out and fall on the ground. The 75t's are magnetically connected, this is friggin fantastic! Such an improvement, can't say how much I love this as they stay in there, in fact the magnet is so strong that you have to be intentional to get them out. Gripe Number 3: The on earbud buttons
I found the 65t's button on the earbuds themselves to be a bit stiff/hard to press and having additional pressure on my ear was a tad uncomfortable. The 75t's have much more sensitive buttons, and I love that they are single buttons, yes there are different combinations to remember but I feel having softer buttons is a huge plus. On to the PRO's! The sound:
I think the sound on these is definitely a tad better that the 65t's, there is a lot more bass, and I do mean A LOT. In fact I need to turn down the bass a little through the Jabra app, I guess you could say too much bass is a negative, but I enjoy hearing the lower end on all my songs. Battery life:
I am getting an average 7.25 hours using middle volume, if I keep the volume high, the run time is a little lower, roughly 6.75 hours. One thing I haven't tested is run time without using the EQ in the app, I'm sure if I left the EQ as default or flat I could squeeze a tad more out? Also the case packs a lot more backup charge than the 65t's, overall a huge jump from the 65t's. Hear through:
One of my favorite features is hear through...I can't rave enough about it as I use these primarily in an office setting and not having to take them out to hear co-workers or have conversations is a huge plus for me. The Case:
Fantastic improvements on the case, love that it's magnetic, magnetic earbuds and strong ones at that, no more lost earbuds. Charge port:
USB-C! Being that the industry is making a change to USB-C it's nice to have one less cable to support. To the CON's! The Bass:
One could say the bass is a tad to strong? However I rather enjoy it, I'm a big over the head, can wearing guy so getting a little more bass out of my on the go headphones is a rather nice plus, but some could be turned away. Ear bud magnets:
The magnets holding these little guys in are strong, and with the ear buds being tiny they can be difficult to get them out. The other side of this is they won't be easily lost, so again choose your battles. Overall thoughts:
I love the fact you get so much better battery life (and case battery too), strong bass, and great sound in such a tiny profile. Not to smash on the Air-pods, but these 75t's stay in my ears, I don't have a fear of them falling out during workouts, and they fit just as snugly (heck if not better) as the 65t's. I'm excited to use these in the warmer months on my longer bike rides. I think just the extra battery life these things pack to last me the work day and not need to do a mid day charge is a huge win and a reason to purchase and or upgrade.

They pair fast, sound great and have wonderful battery life and cheaper than airpods or Galaxy buds (which I've owned before). Their app isn't that great but it isn't buggy. So I'd highly recommend these over platform-specific buds any day.

review_title: Earbuds popped out of my ears and random audio disconnects
review_text:
I had purchased the Elite Active 65t's right before the 75t's came out. I have been very happy with the 65t's, but I was curious what improvements had been made so I decided to buy the 75t's to see how they compare. Here are the improvements I saw, in comparison to the 65t's:
Plusses:
* Strong bass sound
* Longer battery life
* No video and audio syncing issue (this is probably my biggest pet peeve with the 65t's, but I don't use them for this purpose very often)
* Smaller size - both earbuds and case
But there are two major downsides. Negatives:
* Earbuds can pop out of ears when doing physical activity
* Connectivity was lost on several occasions. These two negatives are showstoppers. For me, the earbuds popped off on multiple occasions when I was lifting weights. You definitely do not want to be distracted with your earbuds flying around the gym in the middle of a rep. This never happened to me in all the time I used my 65t's. Also, when they didn't come off, there was still that feeling that they weren't completely secure in my ears - I kept playing around with them to adjust the fit. So I ended up doing an experiment: I put each set of earbuds in my ear and then moved my mouth and jumped around to see if I could loosen the earbuds from my ears. I was able to get the 75t's out within a few seconds just from moving my mouth around. I could not get the 65t's out though, no matter what I did. They're that good at staying in your ears. By the way, the issue was not the earbud tip because I tried all sizes and even tried to use the same one provided with the 65t's. Regardless, they still popped out. The connectivity issue happened to me several times in the middle of a run. Many times, the audio would cut in and out. And a couple of times, the audio completely disconnected. This happened to me one time in the middle of a run. When you're in that running zone high, you don't want to have to stop and deal with restarting your earbuds. Also, I had updated the firmware and Jabra sound app to the latest versions so that was not the issue. Again, I experienced none of these problems with the 65t's. I really wanted to keep the 75t's due to the plusses I noted above - in particular, the quality of the sound is a huge improvement. But it's really annoying to have wireless earbuds that pop out of your ears and to have the audio randomly disconnect, especially during a run. So in the end, I returned them and now I'm back to using my 65t's.

review_title: OUTSTANDING upgrade from Elite 65t! Worth the price...
review_text:
Purchased these to replace my original Elite 65t buds (which I love). After trying a dozen high end wireless buds I settled on the 65's for the comfort, battery, and quailty! When I saw my beloved buds had an upgraded version, I did NOT hesitate and I am glad I bought them! Set up is straight forward, pair with phone and they work! They use the same Sound+ app from Jabra. The say they reduced the size by 20% and theres no doubt, they actually feel like they shrunk them by 50%... They seem ti fit a little deeper into my ear so they are a little less obvious compared to the 65t. They also offer the same comfort as their predecessors, I can wear them all day long and forget they are in my ears - trying doing that with ipods! They are also just as secure, I have not once found myself trying to adjust or reseat them? (tip- nobodies ear canals are the same left/right, my left is larger than my right. so on the left bud I have the medium silicone and on the right I have the small one. So play with the sizes and find something that works - it also doubles the longevity of the silicones if your only using 1 of each). The best thing is they have a longer battery life, I can get through an entire work day (shutting them off at coffee and lunch only) listening to music and taking calls. The carry case has also been redesigned which is a huge upgrade! I found the 65t case to be a bit awkward or finicky to open; not these, the lid is magnetic and super easy to open! They also added magnets to the inside, so you dont have to worry about the buds sitting in the case in the correct position. When you get the bud near the hole it sits in the magnet actually pulls it from you finger tips and snaps them in place and they are firmly held in place (even when flipped upside down with the cover open)
As for sound, they have the same quality sound as the 65t but with a little more bass, the Sound app allows you to fine tune some of the settings. again your looking at ear buds - dont expect to get the same sound your going to get from a huge set of cans! If your going for size, duration, and convenience then this is it! Sound quality is EXCELLENT for a true wireless earbud. They have also added new button features to the buds them self (maybe its the firmware?) either way for example - you can now press the left ear button to switch off or on the Hearthrough feature, etc. FYI - out of the box there was a firmware update (though I dont know what it did)
PROS:

very very comfortable
tiny (especially compared to the 65's)
long battery life
case is a charger
new improved carry case (its significantly smaller) also added magnets
quality sound
quality build/feel
CONS:
no wireless charging
if you want only one earbud in; you can ONLY use the right one!? Maybe the 85t will allow you choose either ear? the price! (BUT I believe they are worth it)

review_title: Nice sound, good fit & battery life....unfortunately left ear bud drops.
review_text: Have had many different TWS bluetooth ear buds the past couple years, as well as too many bluetooth to 3.5mm stereo receivers (and dozens of in ear/canal headphones). I'll confess to being somewhat of a in ear/canal headphone junkie. Had high hopes for the Jabra 75t. Unfortunately these are being returned, as they have the left in ear piece drop out issue that many other users seem to be experiencing. I've updated firmware through the app twice as the software from Jabra comes out, but this issue still present. Connecting to an iPhone iOS 13.x (always latest available). Don't have this drop out problem with other setups. The 75t sound signature is nice, very warm and controlled, but still with plenty of mid and upper range. The app helps with EQ to dial in the sound style you like. Battery life is better than I need, didn't go for detailed testing on this feature, but easily lasts longer than my listening sessions, 3-4 hours at a time. For talking, the microphone/noise cancellation works well, but can't best the Apple Powerbeats Pro. Many times when using the 75t, the person on the other end complains they can't hear my voice well, like it's distant, as compared to the same environment with the Apple Powerbeats Pro. I didn't really buy these for the mic feature, mainly for the sound isolation and listening to music....my comments just to compare mics on a TWS set I have in a similar price range. Fit is awesome. The Jabra 75t is the best of any TWS bluetooth in ear I've tried, ear hook or no ear hook design. Noise isolation is also very good, easy to seal in your ear. When sealed, you can use a low volume and still have a little feedback from the surrounding environment, but with volume levels approaching half way, outside noise is easily overpowered. My use the past couple weeks has been walking or typical indoor around the house. Most in ear buds (even those with ear hooks, or wired solutions) I have to constantly readjust, or they simply fall out or lose the seal. Not the 75t. Only need to adjust every half hour or so. Hopefully the left ear bud drop out issue will get solved.....the fit and sound signature was such that these could have been my only TWS solution.

Jabra has improved on their 65t earbuds in every way. These are smaller, lighter, and more comfortable, while still offering outstanding audio performance. The case has also been improved, with a magnetic closure and USB-C connectivity. The battery in the case is rated for adding an additional 21 hours of charge to the earbuds' exceptional rating of 7.5 hours of continuous audio playback. With their default settings, the 75t's heavily privilege bass, but the excellent Jabra app allows you to tweak the sound profile to match your listening preferences. When tuned appropriately, mids are distinct, with crisp, clear highs. Bluetooth 5.0 means that you can connect with two devices simultaneously. Pairing and connectivity are excellent. Controls are as good as they are on any other earbuds, which is to say they aren't necessarily intuitive to me, but they work well enough. Generally I prefer to control my volume with my phone, but the audio pass-through enabled by pressing the left earbud is a handy feature. Overall, these are an excellent AirPod alternative, with quality construction, excellent features, and great audio. Highly recommended.

review_title: UPDATED: Call audio leaves much to be desired
review_text:
For transparency, I currently own the older Jabra 65t Active earbuds and love them. They fit great, are comfortable for long periods of wear, sound great for music and calls - callers can hear me well (although there is no active noise cancellation on the mics so they hear EVERYTHING), and battery life is as advertised. I've been waiting to buy the 75t because I wanted some wireless earbuds that were a bit smaller and mostly wanted to see what the next generation could offer. Overall, I wasn't disappointed. There are many new features - not anything class-elevating - that mostly fixed annoyances with the 65t. Unfortunately, the first day used them (I've only had them for about 4 days now), I noticed the most annoying problem with phone call audio. Callers can hear me just fine, but the audio on my side of the call is HORRIBLE! Primarily, the audio level is very low - enough so that I need to turn the volume up to the highest setting to hear average level audio (I'm not hard of hearing). And either in addition to that or because of that, there is an annoying amount of hiss that accompanies the caller audio. I'm not certain if it's an amplifier gain problem, or bluetooth encoding problem, but the hiss is only there when there is audio (think noise gate). Honestly, it sounds like the decoded audio stream within the headset is not entering the amplifier with enough gain (from a technical perspective). How do I know this isn't just an issue with the phone (Samsung S9)? Because during the call, I switch from the 75t earbuds to the 65t earbuds and the problem goes away. I'm back to beautiful call audio with plenty of volume and no "amplifier" noise. I switch back to the 75t in the same call, problem reappears. I'm working with customer service now to understand if there is anything that can be done to clear this. The earbuds were upgraded to new firmware as soon as received them so I can't tell if this is something that changed with the new firmware and there is unfortunately no way to downgrade the firmware to see. If I'm unable to find a resolution, I'll need to consider returning these as I will only use them for media audio and not calls. That could be enough for certain use cases, but it would be annoying to need to switch between earbuds just to get decent call audio quality. I'm hoping the issue can be fixed with software changes and is not a generic design flaw. I'll update this review if I get any decent answers, but for now, it you want Jabra true wireless earbuds and consistent phone audio quality, buy the 65t instead. Updated 3/30/2020:
I've had a few more interactions with Jabra customer Service and unfortunately, according to them, the noise I hear during the phone call is by design and is a result of the low-power design of the earbuds. They gave me some reset options to try on the earbuds that made no difference. What I didn't originally report were some random volume inequality problems between the left and right earbuds during a phone call (media is fine). What was odd about this is that the "noise" I hear would actually play at the same volume level on both earbuds, but the call audio would sometimes be louder (more than 50%) in the right earbud. I would have to remove the right earbud forcing the bluetooth connection between the earbuds to pause, reset, or something (the call was still in progress during this process). Replacing the right earbud would apparently reset the connection between the earbuds and the volume would equalize between both. It's unfortunate that call audio quality is apparently being sacrificed for battery performance. I would love to keep my 75t earbuds if the call audio quality was the SAME as the 65t at the expense of battery loss because all of the other features, including media audio quality, are fantastic and worth the higher price. But as Jabra is supposed to be known for fantastic support with phone calls, I can't in my right mind keep the earbuds and put up with annoying call quality (30-40% of my day). I really do think there is an engineering/software resolution to my problem - even if it's something as "simple" as providing the ability for me to sacrifice battery for higher audio output (well above the noise floor) on phone calls. But since I can't seem to get past the first line of customer support (I requested my problem be run past an engineer), I decided to return the 75t and continue to use my 65t - which I'm still very happy with.

review_title: Amazing sound quality, but not the best device for every situation
review_text: Let me start off by saying I’m absolutely floored by the sound quality of these earbuds. I’m sure some will disagree, but I’m more impressed with the sound of Jabra than with Bose and Klipsch. Jabra is the best IMO at providing both rich bass and crisp treble. Headsets are typically one or the other; heavy bass good for hip hop, but poor treble for classical. Or heavy treble good for jazz, but poor bass for dubstep. What about genres like EDM that sound best with both? I listen to a mix of music styles, so I really appreciate Jabra’s ability to handle them all quite well. If you install the app, you can tweak the sound even more by using their equalizer. Listen to a lot of podcasts or audio books? Use the “speech” preset so voices are clearer and less “boomy.” Want more bass or treble? Want smoother or more energized sound? There are options for that, too. Or you can custom adjust the range yourself. The earbuds sit in my ears quite comfortably, and seal tight keeping sound both in and out. So much so that they are nearly as good as earplugs. Which is why Jabra included a HearThrough option that uses a digital technology that brings outside noises in should you wish to. This is good for when you are outside and want to be aware of traffic sounds, or around other people and want to hear what they are saying without removing the buds. In the app, you can adjust the volume of the HearThrough as well as add soundscaping noises to them. Such as pink or white noise, nature sounds (rain, birds, waves, etc.), or ambience like cavern or crowd. This can be calming when at work (assuming earbuds are allowed) or resting. * NOTE: Regarding HearThrough outdoors. Be aware that it picks up the sound of moving air. Whether from your speed or the wind or both. I took these earbuds along with me on a bike ride and found the air noise dreadfully annoying. With HearThrough off, they were fine. But it also meant I had to be more visually aware of my surroundings since I couldn’t hear them. Something to keep in mind if you want to use them while jogging or the like. While these earbuds are good for relaxing, I would not recommend them for sleeping. Not unless you are a back or stomach sleeper. The buds do fit nicely into your ears, but they stick out a bit. So those who sleep on their sides or move around will find them uncomfortable, perhaps painful. Even soft pillows will put pressure on the buds and jab them into your ears, giving a new meaning to the name Jab-ra. (See what I did there?) When using a headset daily, I personally prefer those that sit around the neck and have retractable earbuds. Such as the LG TONE Platinum. This allows me to keep the headphones on me in a resting position without having them in my ears. I can quickly pull them out and put the buds into my ears for an incoming call, or conveniently listen to audio as the need arises. The Jabra Elite 75t Earbuds makes this more difficult. While they are great for when I’m dedicating time to listen—such as doing household chores—they are less convenient when I want to carry them around throughout the day. Plus, they are much easier to lose (since they are so small). There are silicone cases designed for this set (such as ASIN: B083FFBM4J) that have a carabiner you can attach to a belt loop or bag/backpack. That could help the buds be more accessible while with you, but I still envision the process of pulling them out quickly enough for an incoming call to be slow. Just something to keep in mind. Overall, great sound quality, but uncomfortable when lying down. Picks up wind noises outdoors when in HearThrough mode. That said, I find them to be a nice option for the right situations.

After doing my research, I settled for the truly wireless Jabra Elite 75t and have had them for around a month and got them for a holiday gift, before the active ones came out. The active ones are submersible, which may be nice for peace of mind, but the IP55 rating of the non-active ones is fine for the gym or in rain. So far, these earbuds have been great! There are only a few minor quirks. Pros:
-The sound's great
-Bluetooth connection to 1-2 devices is seamless (by the time you take them out of the case and put them in, it's connected! So easy compared to my old Jaybird X2s!) -The tactile buttons are great - it's not uncomfortable to push them; light pushes will do
-Hearthrough works very well
-The passive noise cancellation is very good
-The seal's great, and they rarely come loose, even at the gym
-The phonecall quality is great
-The battery life's outstanding
-Indicator LEDs about battery life are intuitive, informative, and non-obtrusive
-The case is small, light, and the earbuds won't fall out accidentally due to magnetic attachments and lid closure
-The buds themselves are also light and compact
Cons:
-With hearthrough activated, you get a slight hissing sound in quieter environments. It's not really noticeable when music is playing, but can be mildly annoying for podcasts and audiobooks
-If hearthrough's activated and nothing's playing, the hearthrough occasionally cuts out, so you hear your surroundings, then not for a second, then hearthrough reactivates
-The left earbud's sound occasionally drops for half a second. This is rare, but regular (every 2-3-ish hours)
-Sometimes the left earbud doesn't connect, and I have to put it back in the case and take it out again to connect it to the master right earbud
There's also a little room for improvement:
-It would be nice if the buds and case could be made to chirp from the app so you can find them more easily if lost
-I'm not sure how water resistant the case is. It doesn't need to be submersible, but an IP55 rating or so would be nice
The cons and places for improvement are minor at the end of the day. Overall, these are light, comfortable, stay in, have great sound and call quality, and are super-convenient. If you're looking for a pair of truly wireless earbuds for all-around use, from commuting to housework to the gym, these are a great choice.

review_title: Good sound - great case - bad controls (compared to previous model / 65T)

The sound IS an upgrade, they sound pretty good; a bit more bass and clarity of the 65T, from what I can tell. The controls are a definite downgrade. The rocker on the left ear of the 65T is a FAR superior control than the pushbuttons of the 75T. Not sure why Jabra decided to change what was GOOD without adding any features. I especially hate the volume controls. Previous controls on the 65T used the rocker on the left ear so you can turn sound up or down in increments. On the 75T you press and hold the left ear to turn down or right ear to turn up. The longer you press the more the volume changes. So if you just want to step the volume up or down one notch, you're WAY better off using the phone controls. It's impossible to change the sound "just a little." I've kept the 75T for now trying to get "used" to the controls. The sound improvement makes me keep them. The TERRIFIC improvements to the case (magnetic on the 75T) is definitely a plus if you are ever holding the case anything but upright. Battery life is so good that I don't even worry about it...but the way I used the 65T it was never an actual concern. Jabra - You made a nice headset taking forward steps in design and sound. You made a backward step in functionality in my book. Bring back the rocker. Of small consequence - one activity I use the headphones during is washing the car. This is a 2+ hour job for me. Using the 65T I'd never had problems with connectivity with the phone (Pixel 3XL) in my left pocket, and the headphones always stayed in my ears just fine even if I had to take them out for a second (with wet hands) and put them back. I've used the 75T one time while washing the car and noticed (with the same setup - phone in the left front pants pocket) some "choppyness" with the connection. I also had trouble getting the headphones to STAY in my ear after I had taken them out once. I had to stop everything to completely dry my hands, inner ear, and headphone before they stayed in place again. Can't imagine if I was sweating... This problem will make them a deal breaker for me and then I will return them to Amazon - I'll get "used" the the sound of the 65Ts again.

Unfortunately, i've already gone through two versions of these that i've bought and exchange/return from BB. My first copy, the left earbud would never pair unless the L&R earbuds were virtually touching each other. Move them apart about 2 inches, and the left bud would lose connection. Firmware update, unpair/pair, reset...none of trouble-shooting resolved the issue. Went back to BB and exchange for another copy. L&R buds paired better and stayed paired...for a little while. review_text:

I have never enjoyed the sound of brands like Sennheiser or JBL, as the bass always seems underpowered, and the sound tinny. I basically have three boxes to check to make me happy about buds:

2) Sound versatile enough to either pump me up or calm me down

review_title: If you own an iPhone, don't get these.
review_text:
I wanted to review my Jabra Elite 75t's but in full transparancy, I ordered them through Best Buy because I wanted the solid black versions. I have been using my Jabra Elite 75t's since the first day it was available to purchase. Here is a quick breakdown. Sound is great. You can pick from a list of equalizer presets or create your own custom preset. Call quality is good. I use these for my buisness calls and overall the call quality has been very good. From here, things start to fall apart if you are an iOS user. Problems:
The advertised feature that states you can connect to two devices at the same time and switch between them is false. It simply does not work and Jabra support has told me that it's due to a change made to the latest version of iOS and they have no idea if and when this will be resolved. If you are using you iPhone to listen to music and the other iPhone or iPad gets a text message or anything that has a notification. If will stop playing your music if you switch over to the other device. When you try to switch back to your iPhone to continue listening to music, it won't work. Most of the time I have to disconnect my Jabra and establish a new Bluetooth connection. There are many other examples that break when connected to two devices. It's easier to just say, it does not work. My Jabra's turn off while in my ear from time to time for no reason. Sometimes one earbud stops and the other continues. The connection the the Jabra App displays incorrect battery life sometimes. The "Passive" noise cancellation is simply not good but this was a given since its not real noise cancellation. If you try to use Siri, it only works on the last device you connected too which is counter intuitive. So let's say you consider your iPhone the primary device for using your Jabra and your iPad is a secondary device for things like Netflix or YouTube. If you connect your iPad second, all Siri request go to the iPad. This means you need to connect your devices in reverse order. The biggest frustration I have is that the Jabra's simply don't provide you with the functionality they advertise. The main reason I picked them is to have two devices connected at the same time and this simply does not work. I experienced issues from the start and despite many emails with Jabra support, they would not provide me a refund. If I could get a refund, I would purchase the Air Pod Pro's. So if you are an iOS user, I would stay away from the Jabra Elite 75t's. They are very frustrating to use and I think you would be disappointed considering the high cost you are paying for them. Save an extra $50 and get the Air Pod Pro's. I got the Air Pod Pro's for my teenage daughter who uses them all day long and they have been fantastic for her.
I'm absolutely impressed. Really good sound. I don't see why you would need anything better. And if it is I got to have them.

review_title: An improvement on the already great 65t Elite Active
review_text: First and foremost: yes, they do sound better than the 65t. Some reviews seem to indicate otherwise, but to me the difference was night and day - much more pronounced bass and cleaner highs. Maybe that's an improvement built into the app, such as a default EQ setting that alters the sound profile in a beneficial way. I don't know - all I can say is I was wowed when I played music from the 75t's. The other big improvement is actually multi-fold - the case. The new case has USB-C, which should afford faster charging. The case itself is a significantly improved shape. It's both flatter and smaller than the 65t case, so it can now sit upright where the 65t case could only lay on its back and wobble, and the case lid is magnetized so it closes and stays closed until you need it, and it's a lot easier to open than the 65t case. In addition, the earbuds themselves are magnetized so they flop into the proper orientation to charge without any work on your part. They just kind of go where they need to be. Bonus "feature": because the earbuds are magnetized, they will snap to each other, which might prevent one from going missing. I hope everyone who gets these makes sure to get the accompanying app. It's the key to getting the most out of the sound. It has a customizable EQ along with some presets, and you can now save your own EQ setting for later use. It also allows you to control the "environmental" settings such as hear-through. They may not claim to be noise-cancelling, but without hear-through on, it's very difficult to hear the outside world. I can't speak to battery life yet, having only used them for about 4 hours, but so far they're still chugging along without an issue. The case has kept them at 100% and the case doesn't seem to need a charge yet. The 65t had impressive battery life and these are supposedly better. These are a pretty significant step up from the 65t and while I don't know if I'd say previous model owners should dump their 65ts and move up, I can say that I think most people would be quite happy with the upgrade.

I needed a new headset for my work due to constant conference calls - my previous headset was collar-based and the wiring to the ear pieces broke down. Setup: The setup was a breeze and the complementing app is very easy to use. Sound Quality: The sound quality is great and you can modify the EQ through the companion app. Very good low end and crisp highs with everything in-between. Again, the EQ feature allows you to dial-in your desired sound. Build Quality: These are light-weight and fit very well in the ear. Almost like butter but without the mess. :) The buttons on the buds are responsive and don't require a lot of pressure to activate. Charging: Pretty standard for ear buds nowadays - you charge the case and place the buds in the case to recharge. It is better case than the cheaper buds I bought from Amazon but that is expected at this price point. Call Quality: Calls are clear - no dropouts. Also, my voice comes through as though I was talking directly into the phone. Considering this is the main reason I purchased these buds, I'd say they are excellent for business meetings. Features: Beyond the app integration, there are a couple neat features on the buds that make these desirable over others. The "Pass Through" feature allows you to (when not on a call or listening to music) use the mic to hear the room. This is very convenient when hold conversations with people in a room without needing to remove the buds, which reduces the irritation on the ear from constantly having to remove and replace the buds. Another cool feature is the "Sidetone" option. This allows your voice to come back through during phone calls. If you've ever used an earbud to have a conversation, you know it is a little weird because it's like talking with earplugs. By piping your voice back in, it allows you to have conversations at normal volumes without that earplug feeling. Overall, a great product and would highly recommend if you the price point isn't a bother.

As such, I can't call up my Amazon music through Alexa on the headphones. WTF Jabra... Kind of the whole point for Alexa enabled headphones. Unless something happens to make me truly fall in love with these, I'm sending them back. They should register with Alexa as headphones for Amazon Music Playback. That's almost false advertising!

review_title: Impressive In Every Way Except No Qi Wireless Charging Support A Slight Letdown
review_text: Yeah, I'm serious. These buds are very, very impressive in every way: the construction quality,the ergonomics, the comfort, the ease of use of the controls, and of course, the sound quality -- absolutely stellar. The controls just work. They are responsive and exhibit no quirks.The Bluetooth connection is quick and easy. The sound quality is excellent. There is a LOAD of bass for the bass head like myself. The mids and highs maintain their clarity. The connection is almost perfect. I've had breakups, but they happen rarely. Now, the fit of the ear tips is a HUGE factor. Make sure you try on all 3 pairs of tips for the best fit for the best sound isolation possible. Personally, I like my ear canals to "breathe" and opted for a less snug fit with the medium tips, at the the expense of sound isolation. I'm surprised these don't come with Qi wireless charging. This is the only letdown. You should be happy to know I don't have any of the problems mentioned in the other posts. Perhaps Jabra has tightened their quality control. If you're looking for a pair of quality wireless buds, these are DEFINITELY worth a try!

Moved from the Jabra 65t active to this model. All in all I am happy with my upgrade, the model is smaller, but strangely feels heavier, and the case is also slimmer. The addition of the stronger magnets is noticably better. My reservations are that the noise cancelling seems to be weaker than in the 65t actives, and the new controls take a little getting used to.

Works very well except for certain places it will cut out for a few seconds the sound comes back. I've been using this with 2 android devices (phone and tablet). Using with Netflix or other streaming apps the audio disconnect momentarily, even if the connection is established in bluetooth settings for both audio and calls. When this happens I'd just toggle the audio setting on then off and this works, not sure why this happens. Otherwise these work perfectly. I love the soundscape setting as well.

very comfortable. battery lasts forever. sound quality is excellent. Only one button per ear: Pro, don't have to fiddle with multiple micro-buttons; Con, you can't touch the thing without hitting a button, but those are just mute/un and send in outside noise or not, so not too inconvenient. I don't think it has noise cancellation. They do eventually work their way out of my ears (anti-earwig?). I can hear fine, but sometime the person on the other end says it doesn't sound good. rarely is choppy.

I bought these earbuds for my son's Christmas present. Within one month, sound in the left earbud was barely audible. There was lots of crackling and inconsistent sound. My son contacted Jabra for help and but didn't get it. I spent a lot of money on this gift and expected high quality. If you're looking for good earbuds, don't bother with these. I'll never buy a Jabra product again.

I own the 65t and these are probably up there with them in terms of terrible call quality. It’s clear if no surrounding sound. Get the Samsung or AirPods If you want supreme call quality. Not worth the price.
Love these headphones. Had the 65t’s and they sounded good but didnt fit well. The 75t redesign fixed that issue. I get zero ear fatigue love these 75t’s they also sound amazing!

review_title: Mostly great, but do not play nice with my Garmin watch if worn on left wrist.
review_text:
So I mostly like these. I haven't had any comfort issues, and the hear-through feature works great. Have done plenty of running and have had 0 issues with them staying in place. I have a couple of minor complaints:
1. These work in a master/slave configuration, meaning that the right earbud connects to your phone/whatever, and the left earbud connects to the right earbud. The issue I'm having (and have read of others having) is that when I wear my Garmin music fitness watch on my left wrist (I'm right handed), the music will cut in and out while I'm running. Everything works perfectly if the watch is on my right wrist, so I just switch wrists when I go for a run. It's not a deal breaker, but it's a little bit annoying. It would be great if Jabra could some how give you the option to decide which side was the master. 2. Too bassy. No matter how low I set the bass frequencies on the EQ, there is always a hint of muddiness/boominess to the bass. It's almost as if the EQ doesn't have any effect below 60hz or something. They mostly sound good, but try as I might, I can never get the bass response to sound right. Could just be the way they fit in my ears. I'll probably get some aftermarket tips and see if that makes any kind of difference. Other than that, I really like them. Combined with a music watch, it's pretty awesome to be able to go running and feel like I'm not really having to carry anything with me.
A+

I've always gone the cheaper route with headphones and ive always had complaints (fragility, battery life, sync time) - finally shelled out for a good pair after a recommendation from my boyfriend. Could not be happier. They're durable, they know when you take them out of your ear and the battery still hasn't died on me once. As a cheap guy with high expectations - I would recommend these to anyone.
I am able to connect two different phones simultaneously. The sound is very good and the earpiece is comfortable
Awesome product. Nothing to envy any other brand.

Got these in February. I havent used them a ton but I've had battery issues on a couple occasions. The case is charged and I pull one bud out after being in the case all night and the bud is at 20%. I'm kinda regretting my purchase at this point and wished I would've waited for the galaxy buds plus.

I love my sound, and it's hard to trust reviews - because what someone say's great sound, to me sounds dull, flat bass, distortion at max volume. I like to listen to music loud, max volume. I saw an independent review pop up on my news feed with these headphones, and the review just sounded like something I'd write, so I bought these. These don't disappoint. Sound quality is up there, really up there, clear highs, deep lows. Hard to find earbuds that have good, clear, low bass - these have it! the best part is their app - which lets you adjust the EQ to dial in to your liking. I've been against bluetooth buds due to battery anxiety and fear of them falling out. But so far I think these will do just fine. At max volume, I used 25% of battery power at Max volume in about 1.5 hours - so if that continued, I'd get 6 hours of play time - that's pretty impressive to me. Also - no fit issues, they actually felt more comfortable than my wired buds!

review_title: Good if you look at them as just for exercise.
review_text:
The Jabra Elite 75ts. I have to say, these are my first pair of 'truly wireless' earbuds, and for the most part, I got what I was expecting. Sound:
Sub bass: NoT eNoUgH bAsS
Mid bass: Completely non existent?! Mids: Like a soup that tastes alright but was served cold
Mid High: ????? Highs: Thank god they didn't take the same approach to this as the bass. The sound quality is pretty decent. With that being said, if you are used to Sennheiser mids and highs, these will definitely leave you feeling a bit dissapointed. The bass. Is. Heavy. If anything, a bit overbearing. Do not expect to be using these to have nuanced listening sessions with classical or acoustic music... Lol. The thing that really irks me the most is that you would think that with the bottom end being emphasized so much, the mids would sound more robust, instead they end up feeling quite hollow. They don't feel rich or full despite me messing with the EQ. The bass is definitely at a level where a fast paced EDM track will sound amazing during your exercise. I used the Jabra app to tune my earbuds to a upside down v shape, I feel like this matches my preferred sound signature best, definitely fiddle around with that. I cannot stress it enough, I saw many reviews stating the bass was heavy and I thought it couldn't be that bad, it's like bass was salt and a soup called for 1 tsp and the chef added the whole can. If you like mids, these will leave you feeling like there is a whole layer to the song that is missing, the bass and treble do not extend into the mids. No matter how you EQ it, you will be able to hear the lack of extension. Passive noise cancelation is decent if you get a nice seal on your ears. Speaking of seals, you will need to make an effort to get these earbuds to fall out of your ears. So, very good for vigorous activity or very sweaty people. All in all, a bit dissapointed, but that was because I was looking at these to be my earbuds for day to day. Unfortunately, I can't say they match my personal tastes enough for that to be warranted, there's just an element missing that I have grown very fond of. If I look at these as just strictly for exercise, then these are pretty damn good. Won't fall out no matter how hard you try, sound is decent, truly wireless and the batteries aren't anything to bat an eye at.
Jabra Elite 75t, best wireless earbuds I ever bought. Small but pack a punch. Amazing battery, at least 7 hours with constant usage.

I really wanted a good pair of wireless earbuds and was really excited for try these when i first got them. These earbuds do have a lot going for them but also a lot of bad about them. Pros: -There is a very noticeable sound improvement coming from what i used to use before these which were just 20$ wired earbuds. -This thing can connect with up to multiple devices which is really cool. I can go from a youtube video on my laptop to a video on my phone but just pressing play or pause. -They fit really snug and dont feel loose at all. - Battery life is pretty long. Cons: -No instructions on how to use them that came with the actual earbuds so i had to get the app to connect and learn what single tap, double tap, etc. does on each ear. - Updating took about an hour even though the app said it would only take 15mins
- Either the app or my devices are just really buggy. But the app would never show the correct battery percentage. One time i was checking the charge on my earbuds and it would say 80% so I'd used them for only a couple minutes and it would tell me low battery and when i checked again it said 9%. Another time i plugged my case in to charge since it said it was at 60% but when i plugged it in it turns out the case was actually at 20%. - The app/device doesn't tell you its charge as its charging. (At least mine does that) I started charging it since it was at 0% and after an hour of so of charging the case was still at 0% so i unplugged the charging cable from the case and then it showed that it update? and was at 100%. - You can only use the right earbud independently. Don't know why they chose to do that but i really wish each side could be used independently. - After only a few minutes of using them my ear would already start to hurt. This is where i would switch to using the other earbud and let the other side relax but you can only use the right side independently so there goes that. - The latency is pretty bad. It takes about 2-3 seconds after pressing pause on the earbuds to actually pause songs. -Kind of a con? Maybe its just that these aren't made to work with laptops and mostly for mobile devices but using them with my laptop, I can't use the mic and listen at the same time. Because the device thinks that hear through is on since the mic is on? So i would hear myself through the earbuds from the mic. Conclusion:
I do really like these earbuds for the pros but getting them to actually work and the software for them is just really frustrating. As of now i do not recommend these especially for the price. The cons just far outweigh the pros. Maybe for 80$ or 90$ i could live with the cons but for 180$? Hard pass.
I really love the bass of my jabras. It's really good when listening to hip hop, and rap. It's also really good with movies

review_title: Great product, until the battery stopped taking a charge
review_text: Overall pretty great product. These are designed to be more function over audio quality, so I was not expecting a fantastic music listening experience. The setup was very easy and the sound+ app works great for the most part. However, after about two weeks of using these earbuds, they stopped taking a charge. The carrying case charges, but the earbuds remain dead despite placing them in the case a numerous amount of times trying to charge them. Customer Service is taking quite a long time to get back to me to resolve the issue. In the meantime, the earbuds are not functioning at all. I did purchase these earbuds early in their life cycle, so perhaps these issues will be resolved in the future. Regardless, can't recommend a non-functioning product
